qas.question: What happens to untreated copper that makes it difficult to solder?
What chemical treatment will prevent bare copper from oxidizing?
What's the process by which bare copper gets covered in solder?
What does hot air solder leveling ensure the coated copper will have?
What alloy can no longer be used in HASL because of restrictions on the use of one of its metal components?

plausible_answers.text: provide a better bonding surface or stripped to bare copper

qas.question: Shiny solder is usually fused to do what?
What encourages surface oxidation of bare copper?
Traditionally, any exposed silver was coated with what?
The HASL finish encourages oxidation from what?
What is now used in compliance with the RoHS directive in the EU and China?

context: Matte solder is usually fused to <b5_0>provide a better bonding surface or stripped to bare copper<b5_0/>. Treatments, such as <a1_0><b6_0>benzimidazolethiol<b6_0/><a1_0/>, prevent surface oxidation of bare copper. The places to which components will be mounted are typically plated, because untreated bare copper <a0_0>oxidizes<a0_0/> quickly, and therefore is not readily solderable. Traditionally, any exposed copper was coated with <b7_0>solder<b7_0/> by <a2_0>hot air solder levelling<a2_0/> (HASL). The HASL finish prevents oxidation from <b8_0>the underlying copper<b8_0/>, thereby guaranteeing a <a3_0>solderable surface<a3_0/>. This solder was a <a4_0>tin-lead<a4_0/> alloy, however <b9_0>new solder compounds<b9_0/> are now used to achieve compliance with the RoHS directive in the EU and US, which restricts the use of lead. One of these lead-free compounds is SN100CL, made up of 99.3% tin, 0.7% copper, 0.05% nickel, and a nominal of 60ppm germanium.
